Marguerite hasn’t written since her request for some money to help them
produce a pilot kit. You have a copy of the letter I wrote to her
following your and my conversation about making some money available.
I would like to let her know how this money can be paid. I really
have no preference in this matter but would appreciate a copy of any
invoices or bills they might turn in. This is just so I will know
what is going on. Perhaps you can give me some suggestions as to
how this might be handled and I can forward them to Marguerite. During
my visit with Elizabeth Golterman in Cincinnati, we talked about this pilot
kit and future production and developments. Elizabeth was very anxious
that money would be included in the budget (not this pilot kit' budget) to
pay for the staff time involved in the producing of kits. Since she is
on the Advisory Committee who will review the Title VII proposals
she felt that most of the committee were in agreement with her. McPherson’s
comments certainly bore out an attitude of including enough money to pay
for everything.
I sent you a copy of the letter I received from Dr. Willis of the
Chicago Public Schools and also a copy of the letter I sent to Elizabeth
Marshall. Friday I received one of the most pathetic letters I have
ever seen. Liz seems to be caught in the middle of a monstrous power
play. I have decided that the best thing we can do is to sit back and
wait for some reaction from Jennings. As of yet, he has never answered
one of my letters. He has completely ignored two letters addressed to
him, any comment on the letter to Dr. Willis and when I stopped in Chicago
to talk with him and Liz, he didn’t show up for work that day or even
call in. The next time I am going through Chicago, I will attempt to
see him but there appears to be a great deal under the surface and I’m
sure none of this is aimed either at NAEB or our people. It is a purely
local issue. I feel we should sit and wait.
The NAEB stationery and envelopes arrived today. Thanks very much. I
think you had better send some regional directors stationery to John
since I dipped rather heavily into his supply for our initial communica¬
tion venture.
By the way, I sent a general request and information letter to about
sixty-five in the educational.broadcasting field. It is too soon for
their answers but something should be coming in shortly.
Tell Harry we are looking forward to his visit on the 2l|th. I hope
that we can have time for a little conversation. Perhaps if his
schedule is not too crowded, we could have lunch on the 2lith.
